results.notes:
associated with an oak (red oak, i think). Approx. 50% of the stem extended underground. Pore surface has an interesting (to me) color zonation thing going on near the edge of the cap, with well-defined zones of color that progressively get paler the further down from the cap edge.

Staining reactions were hard to figure out on this. Pores initially stained a very dark blue, if not nearly black, but faded to more of a dark reddish-brown. Cap flesh appeared to slowly stain a very faint, pale blue; by the time I returned home (~1 hour), it had turned more of a tannish color, but still faint. Interior of stem stained a faint blue color on most surfaces, accented by what I assume are insect tunnels (?) that were a striking reddish color. I neglected to get an actual picture of the cap surface before tearing it up, but it was kind of a bald, yellowish/tannish color, with a few cracks that had developed.

A NJMA foray collection. This super tiny bolete was found by John Burghardt. It was less than 1" tall, but had well-developed morphology for its size. The pores were a mix of yellow and red. The flesh showed some faint bluing. By the look of it, this species produces liliputian fruitbodies.
It reminds me of another, similar-looking tiny bolete I saw at an upstate NY foray five years ago, obs 217152. Not sure if they are the same species though.

results.notes:
Several fruibodies scattered along a narrow trail oak-dominated deciduous woods. Have collected this species from this exact spot — obs 283636.
Note the red-tinged pores in this fruitbody. L. pallidorosea is most often confused with and mistaken for B. bicolor. Apparently this semblance and the possibility of red pores in mature pallidorosea has also led E. Both to misidentify a collection of pallidorosea as Boletus bicolor var. borealis. The TEF-1 sequence of Both’s voucher 2858 is in line with those of well-identified collections of L. pallidorosea recorded on MO, as well as Both’s paratype or topotype collection of that taxon. This problem is exhaustively analyized in obs 215637 (including a P-tree & sequence alignments). Based on this single misidentified collection and its sequences published in prominent papers on the phylogeny of Boleteceae, B. bicolor var. borealis has been transferred in error to Lanmaoa as L. borealis by Besette et al. (2016). The identity of Smith’s & Thiers taxon is yet to be elucidated.

results.notes:
On old pallet wood (pine?). Cap diameter about 2-5 cm. Taste of fresh basidiome bitter but not overwhelming. KOH turns tissues immediately chrome yellow, followed by a dingy, watery ochre. Cortinoid veil in primordia which is evident as appendiculate margin in older specimens, and may leave inconspicuous fugacious remnants at stipe apex. Annulus absent. Flesh pale, gills mostly adnexed to adnate with a decurrent tooth, rarely slightly decurrent. Somewhat crowded to moderately distant in larger specimens. Spores about 7 × 5, pale melleous in h20, deeper in KOH, dextrinoid. Probably conspecific with observation 404024 and a subsequent fruiting of observation 418762

Growing on unknown urban stump (hardwood?). Caespitose and medium to medium large, pileus with appressed squamules that scatter from the disc. Disc covered in minute, erect tufts of purplish, felty conical squamules (appreciable with handlens). Flesh pale but somewhat yellow in stipe context (herbivory in stipe context) and somewhat deeper yellow at base. Gills adnexed with a decurrent tooth. Pileus diameter about 2-8 cm. KOH merely turns the pale flesh darker and more sordid without a flash of chrome yellow. Base of stipe purplish and silky striate. Primordia with cortinoid veil, sometimes evident on cap margin or as a zone at the stipe apex but generally absent or inconspicuous. Exannulate. Bitter or only slightly so with a lingering taste of rubber. Spores about 7×5 um, melleous in water, honey brown in KOH, dextrinoid

Found a few of these mature to post-mature, yet diminutive, gilled boletes in a mixed hardwood forest dominated by oaks. These grew after the plentiful rains in this area, so moisture was not the determining factor in dictating the fruitbody dimensions; ergo, the small size is probably a genetic feature. The caps measured 1.5, 1.7, 2.6, 2.6, 2.9 and 3.5 cm in diameter.
There was some bluing on the gill edges (seen in photos) after handling. The basal mycelium appeared to be white (as attached thin rhizomorphs in clumps of soil). Due to the size and the delicate condition, I dried these whole, so no info on the color or staining of the flesh.
If one is thinking about calling these P. leucomycelinus because of the white mycelium and calling it a day, think again. According to the 2013 Phylloporus paper by Zeng et al. (Fungal Diversity, 58: 73–101), there are several North American taxa/OTUs distinguished by DNA, and we still don’t know if any of them are leucomycelinus and rhodoxanthus. And it doesn’t end there because, for example, the rhodoxantus-like obs 329265 with its super-long ITS sequence didn’t match anything in GenBank and an LSU fragment derived from another conspecific collection indicated a close relation to a few Asian rather than North American taxa. Thus, Phylloporus of NA is still very much a black box.
Aureoboletus auriporus, Bothia castanella and Tylopilus alboater were found nearby (the first two to be posted on MO soon).

results.notes:
Taste mild with slight bitterness. Pilei mostly applanate. Lamellae rather pale and mostly adnate with a decurrent tooth to slightly decurrent. Some individuals with green stains on pileus surface. Erect purplish, conical squamules at disc which should be viewed in handlens, otherwise appressed as they radiate out toward the margin. Stipe purplish silky striate. Flesh pale, yellowish in stem and bright yellow at base. Pileus context pale, becoming yellow where the context meets the hymenium. KOH makes flesh turn darker sordid watery without a flash of yellow. Veil arachnoid and well developed in the two large basidiomes, but evident as a ragged zone at the stipe apex in most individuals or absent or sometimes evident on the margin. Spores about 7×5 with asperulate warts. All cystidia with brown pigment or hyaline. Abundant brown clavate pseudocystidia. Lactiferous hyphae seen in stipe tissues.
Badidiomes present a range of sizes, especially in pileus diameter and stature of the stipe. Likewise the condition and even presence of the partial veil varies greatly from individual to individual, as well as the evidence of green staining.

—

Mirrored on iNaturalist as observation 150273894 on March 4, 2023.
